{{Expand Polish|Papieska elekcja 1261|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox papal conclave | year = 1261 | notconclave = true | commonname = | dates = 26 May – 29 August 1261 | location = [[Palazzo dei Papi di Viterbo]] | dean = | subdean = | camerlengo = | protopriest = | protodeacon = | secretary = | candidates = | vetoed = | ballots = | pope_elected= [[Pope_Urban_IV|Jacques Pantaléon]] | nametaken = Urban IV | image = Pope_Urban_IV.jpg | prevconclave_year=1254 | prevconclave_link=Papal election, 1254 | nextconclave_year=1264–65 | nextconclave_link=Papal election, 1264–65 }} The '''papal election of 1261''' (26 May – 29 August) took place after the death of [[Pope Alexander IV]] on 25 May and chose [[Pope Urban IV]] as his successor. Since Pope Alexander had been resident in Viterbo since the first week of May 1261, the meeting of the cardinals to elect his successor took place in the Episcopal Palace at Viterbo, which was next to the Cathedral of S. Lorenzo.Cristofori, pp.217-275, and, for the tomb of Alexander IV, pp. 277-285. The actual date of the beginning of the Electoral Meeting (there were, as yet, no Conclaves) is unknown. If the canon of Pope Boniface III (A.D. 607) were still in effect (and there is no reason to think that it was not), then the Election could not begin until the third day after the Pope's burial.''Liber Pontificalis'' ('Doings of the Popes'), in ''Monumenta Germaniae Historica'' Scriptorum Vol. 5 (Hannover: Impensiis Bibliopolae Aulici Hanniani, 1844), p. 164 (ed. T. Mommsen) ==Background== Alexander IV had unwisely continued to pursue the policy of hostility against the [[Hohenstaufen]] dynasty which had been begun by [[Pope Gregory IX]]. In 1261 the claimant was [[Conradin]], King of Sicily since 1254, but he had been supplanted by his uncle and guardian, [[Manfred, King of Sicily|Manfred]]. This was not to the liking of Pope Alexander, who claimed the overlordship of south Italy and Sicily and the guardianship over young Conradin. Immediately on his accession Alexander excommunicated Manfred. Manfred had himself crowned King of Sicily at Palermo on August 10, 1258. ==Cardinals, 1261== Pope Alexander IV (1254-1261), sensitive to charges of nepotism made against his predecessor, Innocent IV (Fieschi), had appointed no cardinals at all.''Annales Sancti Justinae Patavini'' in G. Pertz (Editor), ''Monumenta Germaniae Historica'' Scriptorum Volume XIX, p. 181): ''Iste toto tempore sui regiminis nullum constituit cardinalem; nam cum quidam de cardinalibus edificare Syon in sanguinibus affectaret, quidam vero vellent viros ydoneos promovere, ipse licet haberet plenitudinem potestatis, timore tamen scandali neutram partem voluit exaudire''. [http://www.csun.edu/~hcfll004/SV1261.html Sede Vacante of 1261 (Dr. J. P. Adams).] Two cardinals besides Alexander himself had died since the last Election in 1254 (Aegidius (Gil Torres) and Guilelmo Fieschi); otherwise the electors were the same. {| class="wikitable sortable collapsible" style="width: 90%" style="margin: 2em auto 2em auto;" ! width="*" | Elector ! width="*" | Origins ! width="*" | Order ! width="*" | Title ! width="*" | Date of creation ! width="*" | by Pope ! width="*" | Notes |- valign="top" | Otto (Eudes or [[Odo of Chateauroux]], Castro Radulfi), O.Cist. | Diocese of Bourges, France | Cardinal-bishop | Bishop of Tusculum (Frascati) | 28 May 1244 | [[Pope Innocent IV|Innocent IV]] | on 8 July 1255 he was appointed to the Committee to judge Joachim de Fiore.B. Hauréau ''Quelques lettres d' Innocent'' IV (Paris 1874) (Extrait from ''Notices et Manuscrits'' XXIV.2), 48-79. |- |- | [[John of Toledo]]
(John Tolet) | English | Cardinal-priest | Bishop of Porto | 28 May 1244 | [[Pope Innocent IV|Innocent IV]] | A supporter of Henry III of England; served sixty years in the Roman Curia |- | [[Stephen I Báncsa|Stephanus de Vancsa
(Istvan Bancsa)]] | Hungary | Cardinal-bishop | [[Bishop of Palestrina]] | December 1251 | [[Pope Innocent IV|Innocent IV]] | Archbishop of Strigonia (Esztergom) (1243-1254) |- |- |- | [[Hugh of Saint-Cher|Hughes de Saint-Cher]], OP | Vienne, Dauphiné | Cardinal-priest | Title of Santa Sabina on the Aventine | 28 May 1244 | [[Pope Innocent IV|Innocent IV]] | Legate in Germany, 1253 |- | [[Annibaldi family|Riccardo Annibaldi]] | Roman | Cardinal-deacon | Deacon of S. Angelo in Pescheria | 1237 | [[Pope Gregory IX|Gregory IX]] | Archpriest of the Vatican Basilica. |- | [[Ottaviano degli Ubaldini]] | Florence | Cardinal-deacon | Deacon of Santa Maria in Via Lata | 28 May 1244 | [[Pope Innocent IV|Innocent IV]] | Apostolic Legate in the Kingdom of Sicily, from January 1255. |- | [[Pope Nicholas III|Giovanni Gaetano Orsini]] | Rome | Cardinal-deacon | Deacon of S. '''Pjesma Mediterana''' (trans. ''Song of the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]]''), formerly ''Music Festival Budva'') was a pop music festival held every summer in [[Budva]], [[Montenegro]] until 2011. The festival began in 1992. There have been various sponsors of the festival, including: [[Komuna Belgrade|Komuna]], [[Music Star Production]] and the [[Budva|Municipality of Budva]]. Since 2008, the municipality of Budva, HTP Budvanska Rivijera (a tourist company in Budva) and Copyright Ltd. have run the organisation. The executive producer from 2008 is Copyright Ltd. In 2011, the festival was cancelled reportedly due to financial crisis.[http://www.mondo.rs/s206330/Zabava/Zabava/Muzika/Otkazan_festival_Pjesma_Mediterana.html Otkazan festival "Pjesma Mediterana"];MTS Mondo, 16 May 2011 ==The Festival== Budva's summer music festival is the only open air music festival on the Balkans with a live band. The festival lasts three days. Day 1 and day 2 are the semi-finals and day 3 is the final day. It is usually held in June. ==Hosts and winners== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |+ style="font-size: bigger;" | '''Past presenters''' ! Year !! Hosts !! In [[linguistics]], '''pre-stopping''', also known as '''pre-occlusion''' or '''pre-plosion''', is a phonological process involving the historical or allophonic insertion of a very short [[stop consonant]] before a [[sonorant consonant|sonorant]], such as a short {{IPA|[d]}} before a [[nasal occlusive|nasal]] {{IPA|[n]}} or a [[lateral consonant|lateral]] {{IPA|[l]}}. The resulting sounds ({{IPA|[ᵈn, ᵈl]}}) are called '''pre-stopped consonants''', or sometimes '''pre-ploded''' or (in Celtic linguistics) '''pre-occluded''' consonants, although technically {{IPA|[n]}} may be considered an [[stop consonant|occlusive/stop]] without the pre-occlusion.
A pre-stopped consonant behaves [[phonology|phonologically]] as a single consonant. That is, like [[affricate consonant|affricate]]s and [[trilled affricate]]s, the reasons for considering these sequences to be single consonants lies primarily in their behavior.<ref>{{SOWL|128}}</ref> Phonetically they are similar or equivalent to stops with a [[nasal release|nasal]] or [[lateral release (phonetics)|lateral]] release.
==Terminology== There are three terms for this phenomenon. The most common by far is ''prestopped/prestopping''.<ref>{{SOWL}}</ref><ref>{{ELL2}}</ref> In descriptions of the languages of Southeast Asia, Australia, and the Pacific, ''preploded/preplosion'' is common,<ref>Adelaar & Himmelmann (2005) ''The Austronesian languages of Asia and Madagascar</ref> though ''prestopped'' is also used.<ref>Botma (2004) ''Phonological Aspects of Nasality''</ref> In accounts of Celtic languages, ''preoccluded/preocclusion'' is used almost exclusively.<ref>Ball & Fife (2002) ''The Celtic Languages''</ref><ref>"Pre-occluded" is also used in Laver (1994) ''Principles of Phonetics''</ref> Technically, nasals are already occlusives, and are often considered stops; however, some prefer to restrict the term 'stop' for consonants in which there is complete cessation of airflow, so 'prenasalized stop' and 'prestopped nasal' are not tautologies.<ref>{{SOWL|102}}</ref>
==In European languages==
In [[Manx language|Manx]], pre-occlusion occurs in stressed monosyllabic words (i.e. words one syllable long), and is also found in [[Cornish language|Cornish]] on certain stressed syllables. The inserted stop is homorganic with the sonorant, which means it has the same [[place of articulation]]. Long vowels are often shortened before pre-occluded sounds. In transcription, pre-occluding consonants in final position are typically written with a superscripted letter in Manx<ref>Williams, Nicholas. 1994. "An Mhanainnis", in ''Stair na Gaeilge: in ómós do Pádraig Ó Fiannachta''. Maigh Nuad: Roinn na Sean-Ghaeilge, Colásite Phádraig. §X.4.10. {{ISBN|0-901519-90-1}}</ref> and in Cornish.<ref>Williams, Nicholas. 2006. "Pre-occlusion in Cornish", in ''Writing on Revived Cornish''. Cathair na Mart: Evertype. {{ISBN|978-1-904808-08-4}}</ref>
Examples in Manx include:<ref>{{cite book|last=Broderick |first=George |title=A Handbook of Late Spoken Manx |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AFtiAAAAMAAJ&pgis=1 |accessdate=2009-03-05 |publisher=Niemeyer |location=Tübingen |year=1984–86 |isbn=3-484-42903-8 |id=(vol. 1). {{ISBN|3-484-42904-6}} (vol. 2)., {{ISBN|3-484-42905-4}} (vol. 3)|pages=3:28–34}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Broderick |first=George |pages=228–85 [236] |chapter=Manx |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=BnCqZ5p60VoC&pg=PA228 |editor=M. J. Ball and J. Fife (eds.) |title=The Celtic Languages |publisher=Routledge |location=London |year=1993 |isbn=0-415-01035-7 }}</ref> * {{IPA|/m/}} → {{IPA|[ᵇm]}}: {{lang|gv|trome}} {{IPA|/t̪roːm/}} → {{IPA|[t̪roᵇm]}} "heavy" * {{IPA|/l/}} → {{IPA|[ᵈl]}}: {{lang|gv|shooyll}} {{IPA|/ʃuːl/}} → {{IPA|[ʃuːᵈl]}} "walking" * {{IPA|/n/}} → {{IPA|[ᵈn]}}: {{lang|gv|kione}} {{IPA|/kʲoːn/}} → {{IPA|[kʲoᵈn]}} "head" * {{IPA|/nʲ/}} → {{IPA|[ᵈnʲ]}}: {{lang|gv|ein}} {{IPA|/eːnʲ/}} → {{IPA|[eːᵈnʲ]}} "birds" * {{IPA|/ŋ/}} → {{IPA|[ᶢŋ]}}: {{lang|gv|lhong}} {{IPA|/luŋ/}} → {{IPA|[luᶢŋ]}} "ship"
In Cornish, pre-occlusion mostly affects the reflexes of older geminate/fortis {{IPA|/m/}}, intrinsically geminated in Old Cornish, and {{IPA|/nn/}} (or /N/ depending on preferred notation). It also arises in a few cases where the combination {{IPA|/n+j/}} was apparently re-interpreted as {{IPA|/nnʲ/}}.
Examples in [[Cornish language|Cornish]]: * {{IPA|/m#/}} → {{IPA|[ᵇm]}}: {{lang|kw|mabm}} {{IPA|[mæᵇm]}} "mother" * {{IPA|/VmV/}} → {{IPA|[bm]}}: {{lang|kw|hebma}} {{IPA|[ˈhɛbmɐ]}} "this" * {{IPA|/nn#/}} → {{IPA|[ᵈn]}}: {{lang|kw|pedn}} {{IPA|[pɛᵈn]}} "head" * {{IPA|/VnnV/}} → {{IPA|[dn]}}: {{lang|kw|pednow}} {{IPA|[ˈpɛdnɔ(ʊ)]}} "heads"
In [[Faroese language|Faroese]], pre-occlusion also occurs, as in ''kallar'' {{IPA|[ˈkatlaɹ]}} 'you call, he calls', ''seinna'' {{IPA|[ˈsaiːtna]}} 'latter'. A similar feature occurs in [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]], as in ''galli'' {{IPA|[ˈkatlɪ]}} ('error'); ''sæll'' {{IPA|[ˈsaitl̥]}}, ''seinna'' {{IPA|[ˈseitna]}}; ''Spánn'' {{IPA|[ˈspautn̥]}}.
==In Australian languages== Pre-stopped nasals and laterals are found in some [[Indigenous Australian languages|Australian Aboriginal languages]], such as [[Kuyani language|Kuyani]] (Adnyamathanha), [[Arabana language|Arabana]], [[Wangkangurru language|Wangkangurru]], [[Diyari language|Diyari]], [[Aranda language|Aranda]] (nasals only), and [[Martuthunira language|Martuthunira]] (laterals only).<ref>Mielke 2008:135</ref> Adnyamathanha, for example, has the pre-stopped nasals {{IPA|[bm, ɟɲ, d̪n̪, dn, ɖɳ ]}} and the pre-stopped laterals {{IPA|[ ɟʎ, d̪l̪, dl, ɖɭ ]}}, though these are all in allophonic variation with the simple nasals and laterals {{IPA|[m, ɲ, n̪, n, ɳ , ʎ, l̪, l, ɭ ]}}.
==In Mon–Khmer languages== Pre-stopped nasals are also found in several branches of [[Austroasiatic]], especially in the [[North Aslian languages]] and [[Shompen language|Shompen]], where historical word-final nasals, *m *n *ŋ, have become pre-stopped, or even full voiced stops {{IPA|[b d ɡ]}}.
==In Austronesian languages== [[Hiw language|Hiw]] of Vanuatu is the only [[Austronesian languages|Austronesian]] language that has been reported to have a pre-stopped [[velar lateral approximant]] {{IPA|/ᶢʟ/}}.<ref name="Francois">{{Harvcoltxt|François|2010}}</ref> Its phonological behavior clearly defines it as a prestopped [[lateral approximant|lateral]], rather than as a [[Lateral release (phonetics)|laterally released stop]].<ref name="Francois"/>
[[Nemi language|Nemi]] of New Caledonia has consonants that have been described as ''[[Nasal release|postnasalized]]'' stops,<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Ozanne-Rivierre|1995|p=54}}.</ref> but could possibly be described as prestopped nasals.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|François|2010|p=403}}.</ref>
==See also== *[[Nasal release]] *[[Lateral release (phonetics)]] *[[Prenasalized consonant]]

{{Infobox newspaper |name = Independent Newspaper |logo = |type = Daily [[newspaper]] |format = |owners = |publisher = Independent Newspapers Limited |editor = Ted Iwere |foundation = October 2001 |language = |ceased publication = |headquarters = [[Lagos]] |circulation = |website = {{URL|independentnig.com}} |price = }} '''''The Independent''''' is a newspaper published in [[Nigeria]]. It is based in [[Lagos]]. Independent Newspapers Limited was incorporated on 17 July 2001 and started operations in October 2001. The company publishes the flagship ''Independent'' newspaper, and the ''Saturday Independent'' and ''Sunday Independent''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.independentngonline.com/DailyIndependent/AboutUs.aspx |title=About Us |publisher=Daily Independent |accessdate=2011-05-10}}</ref>
The ''Independent'' is a successor to the ''Diet'' newspaper established in 1997 by [[James Ibori]], a close friend of the military ruler General [[Sani Abacha]]. By 1999 most of the ''Diet'' staff had left since they had not been paid for some months. Ibori, who had been elected governor of [[Delta State]] in April 1999, relaunched the paper in a more colorful and attractive format, but without success. In 2001 the ''Daily Independent'', largely owned by the same publisher, took the place of ''Diet''.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qz9BlWO7ExwC&pg=PA24 |page=24 |title=Repressive state and resurgent media under Nigeria's military dictatorship, 1988-98 |author=Ayo Olukotun |publisher=Nordic Africa Institute |year=2004 |ISBN=91-7106-524-5}}</ref>
In June 2006 Rotimi Durojaiye, an ''Independent'' reporter, was arrested and charged with sedition after writing a report questioning the cost and airworthiness of [[Olusegun Obasanjo]]'s new presidential jet. The charges were dropped later.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VEqZ8rep_A0C&pg=PA154 |page=154 |title=Africa yearbook |author1=Andreas Mehler |author2=Henning Melber |author3=Klaas Van Walraven |publisher=BRILL |year=2007 |ISBN=90-04-16263-1}}</ref>
In October 2009 the Nigerian Union of Journalists forced a closure of the newspaper. Reasons given were that the paper's management had refused to pay four months’ salary arrears and had sacked 21 workers for no just reason. Owner James Ibori intervened, promising to pay the arrears and re-hire the workers, and the strike was called off.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m2weekly.com/feature-cover/ibori-resolves-issues-at-daily-independent/ |work=M2 Online |date=October 21, 2009 |title=Ibori Resolves Issues at Daily Independent |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/Home/5470410-146/story.csp |work=Next |title=Daily Independent newspapers recall 21 sacked workers |author=Idris Akinbajo |date=Oct 15, 2009 |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref> The former managing editor, Ted Iwere, left the paper because of these problems. In January 2010 James Akpadem, the new managing editor, said that Ibori was actively involved in efforts to restructure the paper, which was struggling with debt and unpaid salaries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m2weekly.com/cover-cover/james-ibori-governor-in-the-newsroom/ |date=January 18, 2010 |title=James Ibori: Governor in the Newsroom |author1=Kenneth O Eze |author2=Joseph Ekeng |lastauthoramp=yes |work=M2 Online |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref>
In March 2010 the [[Economic and Financial Crimes Commission]] (EFCC) asked that Ibori attend the Abuja headquarters of the Commission on 17 April 2010 "for interview". The ''Daily Independent'' published an editorial that indignantly defended Ibori.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201004230313.html |title=EFcc Vs Ibori - The Rule of Law On Trial |work=Daily Independent |date=22 April 2010 |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref> Ibori was arrested in May 2010 in [[Dubai]], in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. He lost an appeal against a ruling that he should be extradited to Britain.<ref name=Channels20110416/> By April 2011 the EFCC had Inori on its "most wanted" list, saying "The suspect is wanted in connection with a N9.2 billion case of Criminal Conspiracy,Theft and Misappriopriation of Public funds belonging to Delta State of Nigeria".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.efccnigeria.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1142&Itemid=59 |title=JAMES ONANEFE IBORI |work=EFCC |date=13 April 2011 |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref> On 16 April 2011 Ibori appeared in a British court to charged with a various money laundering and fraud offences.<ref name=Channels20110416/>
==References== {{reflist |refs= <ref name=Channels20110416>{{cite web |url=http://www.channelstv.com/global/news_details.php?nid=26711&cat=Politics |title=Ibori Charged for Money Laundering |date=April 16, 2011 |work=Channels TV |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref> }} {{Major Nigerian newspapers}}

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-135 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1997-067A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1997-067A|title=Navstar 2A-19|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 25030 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIA]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|1816|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|6 November 1997, 00:30:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II]] 7925-9.5,}} D249 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_slot = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|19912|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20449|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.9 degrees | orbit_period = 717.9 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-135''', also known as '''GPS IIA-19''', '''GPS II-28''' and '''GPS SVN-38''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the last of nineteen [[GPS Block IIA|Block IIA]] GPS satellites to be launched. USA-135 was launched at 00:30:00 UTC on 6 November 1997, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D249, flying in the 7925-9.5 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} and placed USA-135 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2a.htm|title=GPS-2A (Navstar-2A)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 13 December 1997, USA-135 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|19912|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20449|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.9 minutes, and 54.9 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} It broadcasts the PRN 08 signal, and operates in slot 3 of plane A of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/project/navstar.htm|title=Navstar|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]|first=Mark|last=Wade|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite has a mass of {{convert|1816|kg}}. It had a design life of 7.5 years, but it actually remained in service until October 30, 2014. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1997}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1997]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}
